title: Italian-English (1894) New Testament Diglot
description: The Italian-English New Testament Diglot, part of a long tradition of Bible translations in Italy, reflects the country's rich historical engagement with biblical texts, from early manuscript translations to the introduction of printed Bibles in the 15th century. Early translations, such as those by Niccolo Malermi and Giovanni Diodati, played pivotal roles in making the Scriptures accessible to the Italian-speaking populace. Diodati's translation, in particular, emerged as a significant Protestant Bible, notable for its scholarly rigor and literary quality that resonated with the Tuscan tradition of Dante and Petrarch. Despite ecclesiastical prohibitions, Diodati's work achieved widespread success, paralleling the impact of Luther's translation in Germany. The Martini Bible became the standard among Italian Roman Catholics, with both Diodati's and Martini's versions being central to Italian biblical literature for centuries. The 20th century saw new translations into contemporary Italian, responding to modern linguistic and cultural sensibilities, yet the historical depth and diversity of Italian Bible translations underscore the dynamic interplay of language, faith, and culture in Italy's religious landscape.
